author: sky.cactus
content: You are greatly hurting readability by using t8n, t9n, and b11r instead of whatever the actual words are.  And you are only saving typing 7-9 characters, which is almost never going to be worth it.

author: samwilsn
content: Plus `t8n` is already a defined term in the internationalization (`i18n`) space ðŸ˜›

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Who knew that replacing all of the letters in a word with a number would cause collisions!
W1o k2w t2t r5eing a1l o0f t1e l4rs i0n a-1 w2d w2h aNaN n4r w3d c3e c7ns!

author: sky.cactus
content: I would further contend that it actually slows down typing in many cases because typing numbers is significantly harder for an experienced typist than typing letters/words.

author: potuz
content:
Ok I was reading all this with amusement, but now when I checkout <@543900561460822016>'s branch to start testing I'm faced with the following log message from the tip of the branch
```
    cmd/evm: support withdrawals in t8n and b11r
```
what the hell is this?

author: lightclient
content: heh - it's the "transition (t8n) tool" and the "block builder (b11r) tool"

author: lightclient
content: they're used to fill the cross client tests run in hive

author: samwilsn
content:
If we're standardizing things, might I suggest:

```
build-tx
build-blk
transition
```

author: samwilsn
content:
or hell, maybe even:

```
mktx
mkblk
```

if we want to be even shorter.

author: peter.davies
content: I don't think the issue is lack of brevity

author: samwilsn
content: No, but `mktx` remains brief while being _way_ more obvious (though still opaque...)
